awd_titl_txt: Workshop: Initiation of the Highly Integrated Basic and Responsive Research (HIBAR) Research Alliance
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide support for a two-day workshop to be held at the University of California, San Diego. The workshop will convene both academic stakeholders (including senior leadership and individual researchers) and organizational stakeholders (e.g. from APLU, disciplinary societies, etc.) to initiate formation of the HIBAR Research Alliance. HIBAR - Highly Integrated Basic and Responsive Research - involves the partnering of academic researchers with experts from business, civic or non-governmental organizations to ensure a real-world perspective during formulation of research questions. The four key tenets of the HIBAR approach are:
1. Embrace the attainment of new knowledge coupled with the solution of important problems
2. Combine academic research methods with practical design thinking aimed at application
3. Engage, from the outset, efforts of academic and real-world experts as equal partners
4. Target time-to-use less than academic norms and more than in direct application
The HIBAR model of using productive collaborative academic-societal partnerships to accelerate breakthrough discoveries offers potential for academic researchers to develop highly impactful research questions that address key societal challenges.

The Workshop will take the first steps to establish the HIBAR Research Alliance (HRA), and to identify appropriate strategies for promotion of HIBAR research. Two parallel themes will be discussed. Theme 1 will concentrate on design of nurturing experiential environments to maximize HIBAR research. Theme 2 will focus on scaling these efforts in order to maximize positive impact. The HRA will concentrate on leveraging Networked Improvement Communities to achieve promulgation of the HIBAR approach.

Successful promotion of academic engagement with HIBAR research, with consequent acceleration of use-inspired research, offers substantial potential for broader impacts through accelerating breakthrough discoveries that address pressing societal challenges and needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Workshop to Plan the Initiation of the HIBAR Research Alliance

 

The NSF Proposal 1828988 “Workshop to Plan the Initiation of the Highly Integrated And Responsive (HIBAR) Research Alliance” Workshop was conceived as a means to assemble a diverse group of individuals representing a diverse set of organizations all committed to improving the relevance and usefulness of university research in a way that advances knowledge while addressing important societal needs.

The Workshop had two synergistic outcomes:
1. Forming a HIBAR Research Alliance (HRA) that is focused on the principles of HIBAR, and 2. Forming a broader more inclusive APLU Council on Research Public Impact-Focused Research (PIR) initiative to serve as an umbrella effort that includes a variety of high public impact-focused research efforts, e.g. HIBAR, Grand Challenges, Communities of Practice, Convergence Accelerators, Germination Research, etc.

The initial outcome of this Workshop was the establishment and organization of the HIBAR Research Alliance (HRA). The HRA’s purpose is to facilitate a resultant outcome which is to boost HIBAR research nationwide in order to increase research designed to address real societal needs. The second, serendipitous outcome was an acknowledgement by the San Diego Workshop participants of the importance of pursuing an inclusive approach to attract and retain researchers to pursue “public impact-focused research.” Initiatives such as HIBAR, Grand Challenges, Convergence Accelerators, etc. are well defined activities with communities of practice and a focus that is perceived as large, irrelevant, and not accessible to individual researchers. Therefore, if the ultimate goal is to increase the engagement of researchers in applying their research to real world problems and to build relationships between the universities and the general public, a framework should be codified that includes well-established efforts of these initiatives (best practices), while also creating a venue for other perhaps smaller, “public impact-focused research” efforts that can leverage the innovation, creativity, and persistence of young investigators and their students.

The Workshop’s two parallel themes addressed these two outcomes which are interdependent, yet synergistic. The first theme focused on ways to attract HIBAR researchers from both universities and societal partners to cooperatively consider specific ways to bolster HIBAR research. A number of good ideas were identified in previous meetings and the San Diego Workshop added clarity and established prioritization. The second theme focused on the factors that would encourage University Partners to form and support the HIBAR Research Alliance, and proposed a framework on how to collaboratively govern.

The ultimate stakeholders in this work are citizens whose lives will be improved directly by enhanced public impact-focused research that solves real problems in society, and, just as importantly, those who benefit indirectly from the academic advances that so often arise from HIBAR, Grand Challenges, Communities of Practice, Convergence Accelerators, etc. research, which in turn yield extremely important spin-off benefits.

Finally, the Workshop provided a venue to assemble a diverse group of experts and practitioners who provided a consensus and a roadmap for launching the HIBAR Research Alliance and the APLU Council of Research (CoR) initiative on Public Impact-Focused Research (PIR). With respect to intellectual merit, the San Diego Workshop provided a foundation for addressing systemic institutional changes to improve incentive and motivational policies (such as hiring, tenure, and promotion procedures) so that this research is encouraged and future scientists can be more easily recruited into research areas designed to address societal needs while producing discoveries. The broader impacts of this Workshop are core to the outcomes namely building a movement both institutionally and culturally that leverages best practices, encourages students to pursue research focused on societal needs, and furthers advancement and leadership in knowledge creation. 

Following the next steps in launching the HIBAR Research Alliance and the APLU Council of Research (CoR) initiative on Public Impact-Focused Research (PIR) are due in significant part to NSF’s vision and investment in providing these North American research leaders with an opportunity to develop a transformational approach to research which demonstrates relevance and impact to societal needs at the local, regional, national, and international levels. The possibilities for impacting people’s lives is limitless.
